title: Justin Rasmussen
text:
I am a PhD candidate in clinical psychology at Duke University training as a clinician, researcher, and teacher. My goal is to bring scientific evidence and lived experience together to improve the quality and accessibility of mental health care.
My research focuses on how community, social, and cultural systems shape mental health risk, promotion, and intervention. I am especially focused on using clinical evidence to develop multilevel interventions that support individual mental health by strengthening families, institutions, and communities.
I grew up in Tanzania and Kenya and got my bachelor’s degree in psychology from Macalester College in Saint Paul, Minnesota. After graduating, I worked with Alex Tsai at Massachusetts General Hospital for two and a half years as an on-site project coordinator for a longitudinal microenterprise, water security, health, and social network study in Mbarara, Uganda.
At the moment, I am a von der Heyden Global Fellow at the John Hope Franklin Center, Instructor of Record for a project-based global health and community psychology class entitled Strengthening Families Across Contexts, and a practicum trainee at the Durham VA and Duke Pediatric Neuropsychology Clinic.
Check out the rest of my website to learn more about my research, clinical training, teaching experience, or to download my CV.

title: Justin Rasmussen
text: I am clinical psychology PhD candidate at Duke University. My primary research interests center on improving access to mental health care in East Africa through professional training and existing community structures. I’m especially interested in understanding the influence of cultural and social context on mental health promotion and intervention. My work has focused on mental illness stigma, collaborative psychosocial interventions with religious congregations, and lay counselor social support. Although not directly part of my research, I also spend a lot my free time learning about the history of psychiatry and research in Africa and trying to improve my Kiswahili.

title: Research
text:
My research focuses on how community, social, and cultural systems shape mental health risk, promotion, and intervention. I am especially focused on using clinical evidence to develop multilevel interventions that support individual mental health by strengthening families, institutions, and communities.
As a part of Dr. Eve Puffer’s Global Mental Health Lab, I have worked on implementing a multilevel intervention in Eldoret, Kenya targeting family-level processes key to child mental health outcomes. Working with mental health professionals and students at Moi University (pictured above) as well as local community leaders, I co-led a combined community-level prevention and in-home family therapy intervention program provided by non-professionals. My dissertation research describes how lay counselors fit within and change families’ existing supportive relationships. I hope to provide a framework for further research that recognizes the contextual embeddedness and skill these counselors bring to increasingly popular community mental health interventions.
Before coming to Duke, I worked with Alex Tsai’s research team at Massachusetts General Hospital for two and a half years as an on-site project coordinator for a longitudinal microenterprise, water security, health, and social network study in Mbarara, Uganda. I continue to contribute to that work as well as projects in South Africa, Liberia, and the US.

title: Justin Rasmussen
text:
Education
Duke University | Durham, NC MA in Clinical Psychology | 2022
Macalester College | St. Paul, MN BA in Psychology | 2012

title: Research
text:
I am fifth-year clinical psychology PhD student working with Dr. Eve Puffer. My primary research interests center on improving access to mental health care in East Africa through professional training and existing community structures. I’m especially interested in understanding the influence of cultural and social context on mental health promotion and intervention. My work has focused on mental illness stigma, collaborative psychosocial interventions with religious congregations, and lay counselor social support. Although not directly part of my research, I also spend a lot my free time learning about the history of psychiatry and research in Africa and trying to improve my Kiswahili.
My teaching experience has included TA-ing graduate statistics and data science courses as well as an undergraduate psychopathology course. I try to teach in ways that emphasize flexible core paradigms that encourage students connect their current knowledge and empowers them to learn independently. I view academia as connected to wider communities and histories. I therefore try to use widely available technologies and engage students in critical thinking about the social, cultural, and historical context of scientific knowledge.
I grew up in Tanzania and Kenya and got my bachelor’s degree in psychology from Macalester College in Saint Paul, Minnesota. After graduating, I worked with Massachusetts General Hospital for two and a half years as an on-site project coordinator for a longitudinal microenterprise, water security, health, and social network study in Mbarara, Uganda.

title: Justin Rasmussen
text:
Research

My research focuses on how community, social, and cultural systems shape mental health risk, promotion, and intervention. I am especially focused on using clinical evidence to develop multilevel interventions that support individual mental health by strengthening families, institutions, and communities.
As a part of Dr. Eve Puffer’s Global Mental Health Lab, I have worked on implementing a multilevel intervention in Eldoret, Kenya targeting family-level processes key to child mental health outcomes. Working with mental health professionals and students at Moi University as well as local community leaders, I co-led a combined community-level prevention and in-home family therapy intervention program provided by non-professionals. My dissertation research describes how lay counselors fit within and change families’ existing supportive relationships. I hope to provide a framework for further research that recognizes the contextual embeddedness and skill these counselors bring to increasingly popular community mental health interventions.
Before Duke, I worked with Alexander Tsai’s research team at Massachusetts General Hospital for two and a half years as an on-site project coordinator for a longitudinal microenterprise, water security, health, and social network study in Mbarara, Uganda. I continue to contribute to that work as well as projects in South Africa, Liberia, and the US. For a full list of my publications, check out the tab at the top of this page, my CV, or my Scholars@Duke page.

title: Justin Rasmussen
text:
Clinical Practice
As a clinician, I am committed to providing evidence-based, culturally sensitive, and trauma-informed care. I have experience working with children, adolescents, and adults in a variety of settings across of range of problems. I am currently in the process of applying to clinical internships. Below are some of the clinical settings where I have trained during graduate school:

Durham Veterans Affairs Medical Center

Trauma Recovery Program

Duke University Hospital Outpatient Clinics

Duke Psychiatry at Civitan Building (Adult CBT and full-model DBT program)
Duke Pediatric Neuropsychology Clinic

Duke Child and Family Study Center

Duke Center for Adolescent and Young Adult Substance Use Treatment (CAST)
Psychosocial Treatment Clinic

Duke Psychology Community Clinic

title: Justin Rasmussen
text:
Teaching & Mentoring

One of the joys of my doctoral training has been the opportunity to teach and mentor students. I am currently instructor of record for a project-based community psychology course funded by Bass Connections titled Strengthening Families Across Contexts. My previous teaching experience has included conducting labs for graduate statistics and data science courses, running discussion sections for an undergraduate psychopathology course, and teaching basic psychotherapy skills to peer counselors in Kenya (pictured above). Through our research work, I’ve helped mentor graduate and undergraduate students at Duke and at our partner site at Moi University.
When I teach, I emphasize flexible core paradigms, encourage students connect their current knowledge, and provide opportunities for them to learn independently. I view academia as connected to wider communities and histories so I try to use widely available technologies (free and open source) as much as possible and engage students in critical thinking about the social, cultural, and historical context of scientific knowledge. As part of my commitment to learning and continuing to develop as a teacher, I am completing the College Teaching Certificate.
Out of an interest in promoting more African voices on mental health, I began curating a multimedia database of resources on Perpectives on African Mental Health & Illness for students and teachers. I hope you’ll check it out and send me suggestions for additions.

title: Justin Rasmussen
text:
A few helpful Resources

Pathways into Clinical Psychology or Global Mental Health
Students often ask me about how to get into clinical psychology PhD programs/global mental health. I always recommend starting with https://mitch.web.unc.edu/wp-content/uploads/sites/4922/2017/02/MitchGradSchoolAdvice.pdf I recommend you start by reading Mitch’s Uncensored Advice for Applying to Graduate School in Clinical Psychology. I’d be happy to talk with you as well. Email me with a clear subject line and mentione how you came across my profile (so I know it’s not spam). I hope to post a resource on global mental health sometime in the future. ### Learning R Various people often ask me about how to get started using R. For that reason, I curated a very short list of Web Resources to Start Learning R. It’s not perfect, but it’ll get you going. ### Perspectives on African Mental Health & Illness Having grown up and worked in East Africa for most of my life, it’s been important to me to learn about mental health from the perspective of African people, history, and cultures. For that reason, I am working on building a database of resources on Perpectives on African Mental Health & Illness ### Make your own website

title: Publications
text:
Rasmussen, J. M., Johnson, S. L., Ochieng, Y. A., Jaguga, F., Green, E. P., & Puffer, E. S. (2024). “Congregation leader and member discussions in a church-based family strengthening, mental health promotion and HIV prevention trial: Intervention” Cambridge Prisms: Global Mental Health. https://doi.org/10.1017/gmh.2024.44

In this paper, I demonstrate how inter-household conversations work as a community-level intervention process that might amplify mental and sexual health information shared during workshops held in Kenyan religious congregations. I discuss how tracking this type of process may be important to understand how interventions might create durable shifts in social context around key health issues like mental health. I also outline future directions for studying congregational settings as unique contexts for mental health and family health intervention, particularly in African countries where these are ubiquitous community institutions.

I discuss how tracking this type of process may be important to understand how interventions might create durable shifts in social context around key health issues like mental health. I also outline future directions for studying congregational settings as unique contexts for mental health and family health intervention, particularly in African countries where these are ubiquitous community institutions.

title: Justin Rasmussen
text:
I am a PhD candidate in clinical psychology at Duke University and a von der Heyden Global Fellow at the John Hope Franklin Center. Across my training as a clinician, researcher, and teacher my goal is to bring scientific evidence and lived experience together to improve the quality and accessibility of mental health care.
I grew up in Tanzania and Kenya. I enjoy running, cooking, writing and reading poetry, and learning about almost everything (especially history).
Check out the rest of my website to learn more about my research, clinical practice, teaching and mentoring or to download my CV.

title: Justin Rasmussen
text:
Contact me
I’d love to hear from you. I can’t provide clinical advice on referrals but I’m happy to chat about research, teaching, or other interests. Send me an email at justin.rasmussen@duke.edu.
If you are a student interested in grad school in clinical psychology or global mental health, check out Mitch’s Uncensored Advice for Applying to Graduate School in Clinical Psychology and then email me with a clear subject line and mention how you came across my profile. I’d be happy to chat about your goals and interests.
If you’re interested in learning R or how to make your own free website like this one, check out my Web Resources to Start Learning R or my GitHub page for this website.

title: Teaching & Mentoring
text:
Experience
One of the joys of my doctoral training has been the opportunity to teach and mentor students. I am currently instructor of record for a project-based community psychology course funded by Bass Connections titled Strengthening Families Across Contexts. My previous teaching experience has included conducting labs for graduate statistics and data science courses, running discussion sections for an undergraduate psychopathology course, and teaching basic psychotherapy skills to peer counselors in Kenya (pictured above). Through our research work, I’ve helped mentor graduate and undergraduate students at Duke and at our partner site at Moi University.


Philosophy
When I teach, I emphasize flexible core paradigms, encourage students connect their current knowledge, and provide opportunities for them to learn independently. I view academia as connected to wider communities and histories so I try to use widely available technologies (free and open source) as much as possible and engage students in critical thinking about the social, cultural, and historical context of scientific knowledge. As part of my commitment to learning and continuing to develop as a teacher, I am completing the College Teaching Certificate.


Perspectives on African Mental Health & Illness
It is my experience that African voices are especially underrepresented in psychological training and teaching. Having sought out these perspectives myself, I began collecting them in a multimedia database on Perspectives on African Mental Health & Illness for students and teachers. It contains podcasts, movies, books, magazine articles, and more.
I hope you’ll check it out, incorporate some of the resources in your teaching, or send me suggestions for additions.

title: Teaching & Mentoring
text:
One of the joys of my doctoral training has been the opportunity to teach and mentor students. I am currently instructor of record for a project-based community psychology course funded by Bass Connections titled Strengthening Families Across Contexts. My previous teaching experience has included conducting labs for graduate statistics and data science courses, running discussion sections for an undergraduate psychopathology course, and teaching basic psychotherapy skills to peer counselors in Kenya (pictured above). Through our research work, I’ve helped mentor graduate and undergraduate students at Duke and at our partner site at Moi University.
When I teach, I emphasize flexible core paradigms, encourage students connect their current knowledge, and provide opportunities for them to learn independently. I view academia as connected to wider communities and histories so I try to use widely available technologies (free and open source) as much as possible and engage students in critical thinking about the social, cultural, and historical context of scientific knowledge. As part of my commitment to learning and continuing to develop as a teacher, I am completing the College Teaching Certificate.
Out of an interest in promoting more African voices on mental health, I began curating a multimedia database of resources on Perpectives on African Mental Health & Illness for students and teachers. I hope you’ll check it out and send me suggestions for additions.

title: Contact
text:
I’d love to hear from you! Send me an email at justin.rasmussen@duke.edu. I can’t provide clinical advice or referrals but I’m happy to chat about research, teaching, or other interests.
If you are a student interested in grad school in clinical psychology in the US, I recommend checking out Mitch’s Uncensored Advice for Applying to Graduate School in Clinical Psychology. You may also find recordings of Duke’s 2022 Inside Look program useful (organized by the brilliant Armen Bagdasarov). If you have more specific questions about the process or global mental health, feel free to email me with a clear subject line and mention how you came across my profile. I’d be happy to chat about your goals and interests.
If you’re interested in getting started learning R (perhaps to make a free Quarto website like this one) check out these Web Resources to Start Learning R I put together.

title: Clinical Training
text:
As a clinician, I am committed to providing evidence-based, culturally sensitive, and trauma-informed care. I have experience working with children, adolescents, and adults in a variety of outpatient settings, having delivered evidence-based therapies for mood, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive, substance use, personality, and traumatic stress disorders.
I am currently applying to clinical internships for next year.

Doctoral practicum sites
Durham VA Medical Center

Trauma Recovery Program

Duke University Hospital Outpatient Clinics

Duke Psychiatry at Civitan Building (Adult CBT and full-model DBT program)
Duke Pediatric Neuropsychology Clinic

Duke Child and Family Study Center

Duke Center for Adolescent and Young Adult Substance Use Treatment (CAST)
Psychosocial Treatment Clinic (child- and family-focused CBT)

Duke Psychology Community Clinic (department training clinic)

title: Research
text:
Recent Work
Rasmussen, J. M., Johnson, S. L., Ochieng, Y. A., Jaguga, F., Green, E. P., & Puffer, E. S. (2024). “Congregation leader and member discussions in a church-based family strengthening, mental health promotion and HIV prevention trial: Intervention” Cambridge Prisms: Global Mental Health.

In this paper, I showed how inter-household conversations work as a community-level intervention process that might amplify mental and sexual health information shared during workshops held in Kenyan religious congregations. I discuss how tracking this type of process may be important to understand how interventions might create durable shifts in social context around key health issues like mental health. I also outline future directions for studying congregational settings as unique contexts for mental health and family health intervention, particularly in African countries where these are ubiquitous community institutions.
